awd_titl_txt: RII Track-4:NSF Engineering mixed microbial communities & bioreactor configurations to optimize biotransformation processes for metal and metalloid bioremediation and biorecovery
awd_abstract_narration:
Waste streams from agricultural run-off and industries such as mining typically contain pollutants like metals and metalloids (M&M), which can be toxic and pose a threat to the environment and health. The removal and recovery of M&M from wastewater is crucial to prevent environmental contamination and to develop a more sustainable use of resources. This project proposes to exploit the ability of microbes to transform toxic and water-soluble forms of M&M into non-toxic forms which can be recovered as value-added products (e.g., metallic nanoparticles that can have multiple applications). Under the concept of "together is better", we plan to use mixed microbial communities of fungi and bacteria (relatively unexplored communities) to develop bioreactor systems for metal- and metalloid- biotransformation processes; by increasing the number and diversity of partners in a microbial community we can create more resilient, tolerant, and stable communities with improved biotransformation processes compared to their individual counterparts. The proposed work will (i) provide key fundamental knowledge regarding microbial interactions between fungi and bacteria in mixed microbial communities, a topic of interest to better understand the microbial system in nature; and (ii) lay down the foundation for the development of improved systems for the removal and recovery of harmful M&M from waste streams, which has transformative potential and can revolutionize both bioremediation technologies and future biomanufacturing. 

This project envisions using multi-domain mixed microbial communities (MMCs), specifically the relatively unexplored fungal-bacterial biofilms, for improved biotransformation and bioremediation of metals and metalloids (M&M) from waste streams and biorecovery of value-added products (e.g., metallic nanoparticles) beneficial to society. This project will address some of the main challenges in using MMCs for bioprocessing: the poor understanding of MMCs and the lack of bioreactors to successfully cultivate MMCs and maintain stable bioprocessing. Thus, the goal of this project is to develop and optimize MMCs and bioreactor systems for improved bioprocessing of M&M for bioremediation and biorecovery. As a proof of concept, selenium (Se, a common metalloid found in acid mine drainage) will be used as an example to assess the potential use of the proposed fungal-bacterial biofilm systems for M&M bioremediation and biorecovery in this project. Three main tasks are proposed: (1) establishing fungal-bacterial biofilms with relevant environmental microorganisms and characterizing their structural and mechanical properties using a combination of cutting-edge techniques including magnetic tweezers, shear rheometry, and optical coherence tomography; (2) developing Membrane Biofilm Reactors (MBfR), an emergent technology based on the use of membranes that transfer gas to a biofilm growing on the membrane, to support fungal-bacterial biofilm establishment; and (3) assessing and optimizing reactor performance and stability of MBfRs with fungal-bacterial biofilms for the removal of Se and its recovery. Understanding and controlling microbial interactions in MMCs and developing improved multi-domain bioreactor systems is key to building a sustainable future minimizing pollution and to utilizing waste streams for the recovery of the generation of high-value products.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The use of microbial systems for metal and metalloid (M&M) bioprocessing and biorecovery is an emerging opportunity due to the pressing need of building a more sustainable future without pollution or waste. Microorganisms, such as fungi and bacteria, can transform toxic water-soluble M&M species to (typically) non-toxic value-added products (VAPs, e.g., metallic nanoparticles) beneficial to society. Thus, microorganisms are regarded as green biofactories that can provide cost-effective, environmentally friendly alternatives for the remediation and recovery of M&M from different environmental matrices, and the manufacturing of VAPs. Traditionally, pure cultures or communities of either fungi or bacteria (single-domain systems) have been used for M&M bioprocessing and biorecovery; while this approach has shown promise, it also has its limitations given the lack of functional diversity and redundancy (e.g., having a reservoir of microorganisms that have similar ecological functions) in these systems, potentially resulting in limited bioprocessing and unstable system performance over time. To address some of the limitations by single-domain systems, this project proposed using multi-domain mixed microbial communities (MMCs), specifically the relatively unexplored fungal-bacterial biofilms, for improved M&M biotransformation processing and biorecovery. MMCs can exhibit enhanced properties compared to single-species communities (e.g., increased ecological diversity, robustness, synergistic interactions) which can improve overall M&M biotransformation under a wide range of conditions. Through this project, research was performed to (i) improve our understanding of MMCs, particularly fungal-bacterial biofilms, (ii) propose alternative bioreactors to successfully cultivate MMCs and maintain stable bioprocessing, and (iii) evaluate and optimize the proposed bioreactor systems for their performance and stability upon exposure to M&Ms, specifically, selenium, a well-known metalloid that is commonly found on effluents form acid mine drainage and mining activities.

A strong collaboration between the PIIs group at Montana State University (MSU) on fungal and fungal-bacterial biofilms, and the group at the host site at University of Notre Dame (UND) on membrane biofilm reactors (MBfRs) was established and expanded through this project. Participants of this project (the PI and one graduate from MSU) visited the host institution to obtain training in advanced biofilm characterization methods and utilization of MBfRs. The participants were involved in experimental and laboratory work to grow biofilms on MBfRs and characterize their performance and stability upon exposure to selenium. Notable outcomes from this project include the following highlights:

Development of new knowledge & innovation

  • MMCs biofilms with known selenium-reducing organisms, including bacterium Pseudomonas stutzeri, and fungus Phanerochaete chrysosporium were established. Fungal-bacterial biofilms were characterized and compared to their mono-culture biofilms.
  • Characterization of the mechanical properties of fungal and fungal-bacterial biofilms was obtained. This is a relatively new research area of study, as this kind of characterization has mostly been done on bacterial biofilms. Preliminary findings will aid guiding the future directions to improving the understanding of mechanics in fungal-based biofilms, which is relevant to different research fields (e.g., material synthesis, manufacturing, etc.).
  • New configurations of MBfRs were designed, constructed and evaluated to assess their feasibility to grow mixed microbial communities as biofilms. MBfRs represent highly promising systems for the cultivation of multi-domain biofilms with emergent properties for bioremediation, biorecovery, and bioprocessing.
  • Reactor performance and stability of MBfRs with fungal, bacterial, and fungal-bacterial biofilms upon exposure to toxic species of selenium were evaluated. Overall, it was observed that bacterial and fungal-bacterial biofilms were more efficient at removing toxic species of selenium from a synthetic effluent compared to fungal biofilms. MBfRs with bacterial biofilms presented more operational difficulties, including detachment events and observed suspended growth in the reactor. From the operational point of view, fungal-bacterial biofilms were more stable as they retained bacteria within the biofilms.
  • A peer review articled authored by the PI was published on the potential use of biofilm reactor systems in space. This work included knowledge gained by the PI during her visit at the host institution.

Building capacity 

  • Training of participants on advanced biofilm characterization methods and utilization of MBfRs. The knowledge and skills acquired were transferred to students working on biofilm research at the PIIs home institution.
  • Several high-impact presentations including invited talks by the PI and poster presentations by students.

Professional development

  • The PI (female and Latina scholar) has established as an independent researcher and recently obtained a tenure-track faculty position.

Education & outreach

  • The PI developed a specialized section on fungal biofilms as part of the international Biofilms Workshop, which was offered at UND in Summer 2023. The course was offered to 21 students interested on biofilm research from different national and international universities.
  • A short module entitled Itroduction to Modeling biofilms in COMSOL Multiphysics was developed by a graduate student in this project. This document was intended to help undergraduate and graduate students working on biofilms research to learn a new modeling tool that could potentially be incorporated into their research (To be published online).
